Award.AwardTitle: The Social Dynamics of Early Beothuk-European Relations in Trinity Bay, Newfoundland
Award.AbstractNarration:
In the autumn of 1612, John Guy - the newly appointed Governor of Newfoundland's first official colony (Cuper's Cove) - set sail with fellow colonists into Trinity Bay. Guy hoped to make contact with the native inhabitants of the island, the Beothuk Indians, so as to establish a trading relationship with them. After several days of exploring and visiting unoccupied campsites, Guy's expedition finally encountered a small group of Beothuk on November 6th. Although cautious at first, the Beothuk invited the colonists to share a meal with them and gifts were exchanged. Then the two groups parted ways.

The colonists must have been pleased with the meeting and optimistic about their chances for establishing a long term and lucrative trading relationship with the natives, but such relations never developed. Within a decade, the Beothuk had retreated to coastal areas north and west of Trinity Bay; a century later they were living in the interior of the island, having been forced from the coast by European fishing activity, settlement and hostilities; and by the middle of the following century they were gone-the "last of the Beothuk" succumbing to tuberculosis in the city of St. John's in 1829.

Guy's meeting with the Beothuk marks the end of a critical, but poorly understood period in Native-European relations on the island. This project hopes to uncover new data that will shed light this period through exploratory archaeological excavations at a newly discovered Beothuk site in Trinity Bay. This site was discovered in the summer of 2009, in a location where Guy is thought to have observed "nine savage houses" just days before his famous meeting with the Beothuk. Test excavations in 2009 at this location yielded Beothuk projectile points in association with modified iron nails, worked ballast flint, bottle glass and ceramics that may date to the late sixteenth century. With support from the National Science Foundation, archaeological field work in 2010 will assess the spatial extent and richness of the site, and establish temporal parameters for the Beothuk occupation. The overall aim is to assess whether the site warrants further investigation.

If the site proves to be rich, and indeed dates to the time of Guy's voyage, it stands to make a significant contribution to our understanding of early Native-European relations on the island, and perhaps, offer clues as to why such relations deteriorated in the mid-seventeenth century. On a broader level, this work will offer an archaeological perspective on the earliest chapters of European-Native American history in the New World, and a case study for understanding social dimensions of the European colonization effort.

The project will include a small team of scientists and undergraduate students from the United States and Canada. Students will benefit from the opportunity to engage in collaborative research and work as part of an international team. Data obtained during this research will be disseminated to other scholars in the field. This research will also reach a broader audience, as the story of the Beothuk Indians figures prominently in the history of the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador, and Canada. In the event that additional work is warranted, this research could contribute to the further development of historical tourism in the area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The early contact period is one of the most intriguing eras in all of North American history; it is also a time period that scholars know very little about. This research aimed to explore this critical era as it unfolded on the island of Newfoundland, with the broader goal of understanding the social and economic forces that inform encounter experiences in general.

The island of Newfoundland was home to the Beothuk Indians when Europeans arrived in Newfoundland’s waters at the end of the 15th century. At that time, the Beothuk were coastal hunters and gatherers who had lived on the island for over a thousand years. Europeans initially came to Newfoundland only to harvest fish. They would arrive in the spring, fish throughout the summer months, and return to Europe in the fall; permanent settlement came much later. Historical documents are largely mute on the nature of early encounters between the Beothuk and European migratory fishermen, but those that speak to them suggest a complex mix of hostile and friendly engagements. Later, as European fishing activity and settlement increased in the 17th century, hostile encounters became more common and the Beothuk were forced to retreat into the interior of the island. By the mid-19th century they were “extinct” as a people. 

Our research involved archaeological investigations in Stock Cove, Trinity Bay—the site of a friendly encounter between early colonists and the Beothuk in 1612. Excavations focused on a campsite that was occupied by Beothuk peoples in the 14th century. Our excavation in this area unearthed dozens of stone tools, refuse pits, scattered hearth features, and the remains of animals that were consumed by the Beothuk. Analysis of the animal bones indicates that the Beothuk enjoyed a varied diet and probably occupied the campsite during the spring. Excavations also yielded European artifacts that date to the mid to late 17th century. These objects include hundreds of pieces of ceramic earthenware, tobacco pipes, lead shot, and gunflint. They were probably associated with a nearby migratory fishing station. We also found some evidence that the site was visited by Amerindian peoples (known to archaeologists as the Maritime Archaic) long before the Beothuk, perhaps 5000 years ago.

Our excavations indicate that Stock Cove was the site of a relatively large Beothuk campsite in the 14th century. Historic records also indicate that the Beothuk were visiting Stock Cove later, in the early 17th century. Both suggest that Stock Cove was an important place for the Beothuk. Yet, the Beothuk appear to have stopped visiting the area sometime in the mid to late 17th century. This is when European artifacts first appear on our site, lending support to the notion that the expansion of Europeans into Stock Cove had a significant part to play in the Beothuk’s abandonment of the area. The poor state of Beothuk-European social relations was also an important variable. Owing to the migratory fishing economy, the number of actors involved, and the absence of economic incentives to trade, it would have been difficult for the Beothuk and Europeans to establish and sustain social relations with each other during the first century of contact. Thus, the early contact period was marked by little interaction, and an aura of unpredictability would have characterized most encounter experiences. We hypothesize that these conditions would have made it difficult for both groups to mitigate conflicts later on. The abandonment of Stock Cove by the Beothuk represents one such failure.
